reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good size, lightweight, sharp blade... my new default chopping/slicing knives...
reviews.reviewText: I ordered these after seeing higher end versions reviewed on a food programme. My old go-to knife was a stainless steel santoku, which works really well and I will still use for really large jobs. These are work really well for cooking dinner and smaller jobs though as they are much lighter. I find that I need to be more careful with these though, as they are lighter, thinner, and sharper than my previous favourite The extra focus that is required would not aid my safety in a longer usage time-frame such as a big cooking task requires.The nigiri knife (square one) is optimal for slicing and chopping vegetables and fruit, while the other one works better for meats. These push through the food almost as easily as a "knife through butter". They actually allow a very thin cut on sturdy vegetables like celery, softer items like tomatoes, and ruffage like Napa cabbage, as well as good small slices on slightly frozen meats.At about 10USD, these are a really good bargain for those that need them or those that are skilled with knives. They are quick and easy to hand wash and they seem to stay sharp as long as I take care of them. I am rating these four stars, as I have been using them everyday for three weeks without switching... though I have been extra cautious and I have narrowly avoided injury. As always, your mileage and preferences may vary...

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing Value, Great Tool
reviews.reviewText: This is an amazing story. 40 years ago I originally bought the 8 inch, Thai Knife in a Thai grocery store I shopped at. Back then the knives were being sold for about two to three dollars depending on the store. I tapped the blade while holding the handle, it had a nice ring, to me that suggests spring steel. The blade is thin and durable.Two weeks ago My daughter was helping me cook and I handed her one of the knives she commented how she really liked how functional it was. I asked if she had one, she sighed and said she wants one but they are pricey. So I checked. They run from 50 to 100 USD and up. Then I put in the name, 'Kiwi' and found the same knives, and again so reasonably priced. I ordered them on the spot. What a testimony, 40 years of work, and they still handle whatever I need, and stay sharp. The Angled tip allows a spatula use, and the blade is so sharp that I turn a raw, chuck roast on its side and slice it into two or three steaks. (super sharp, be careful) It will chop, slice, cut, anything you cook with.So, 40 years later I bought the same set as a surprise for my kid. What arrived for a good price of about 12 to 14 dollars, was the same exact knives with the same Kiwi logo. I am blown away at this. So why is this knife cheaper? Remember, mine sees hard use, stressful cuts, weighted down, slashes, chopping, and they are 40 years used by me.They may be cheaply priced, but they are not cheap. To say they are not built as well as some, is true, but what does that really mean? Considering I have used mine almost daily for 40 years, and they have outlived my high-end blades that fade into dullness. As you go up toward the spine of most blades, the metal thickens. At that point, one either regrinds the entire knife or buys a new one. This Kiwi blade being thin, is a big factor in maintaining its razor edge.Take care of them, they will serve you perfectly and will be very enjoyable to use..

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Dirt Cheap, Awesome performance.
reviews.reviewText: I cook daily due to food allergies, I have to make every meal from scratch so that I don't get sick.I use my kitchen knife a LOT. and these knives make preparing meals effortless. forget falling through tomatoes these fall through POTATOES like they are made of tissue paper.They are cheaply made and kinda flimsy looking and I had to hone them a little because the blades had small burrs on the blade when I got them. They were very sharp, just not cleaned up after sharpening.,Despite the cheap appearance and unfinished sharpening job they feel solid when you use them and they are light enough that you don't get fatigue when using them for large meal prep.The first time I used these I took my old kitchen knives and put them away, these took over their place in the knife block. They are just that good.Pretty much these are going to be my daily drivers until I break down and get a hand forged set. I have tried lots of knives in the under 50 price range and these just beat everything else I have used. My knife hunt is over until I get a showpiece set, and that just got put way back on the to do list because these work so well.I don't know what else to say, At the price of $16 for the 2 piece set this is an impulse buy that you won't regret.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2021
reviews.reviewText: These are basically a minimalist design for good inexpensive knives.The handles are small and light, but they feel ok and work.The blade is extremely thin. So it can glide through veggies easily. But it has little weight to help in chopping motions. It's thin enough that the blade can actually bend while cutting.The steel is not super hard, so while I haven't had mine long enough to sharpen, I anticipate frequent sharpenings, but likely to be very quick and easy to get sharp. And out of the box, it came very sharp.If you want a knife with substance and heft, this is not the knife for you.We all have price points. And there's a lot of folks for which this price will do nicely.For what the knife is, and can do, it's a fantastic value.For people that can afford knives with more expensive features, chances are they want something more substantial.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sharp, light weight, great for sushi, jerky and thin cuts
reviews.reviewText: I got them to paper thin slice meats to dehydrate as treat for my pets and works fantastic, Sharp, thin blade, light weight, great to dice and slice now I use them for everything. Even got the smaller six pack knives for the family daily use.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: These knives are great buy at $10 for two. I have a kiwi plastic handled one that I bought about a year ago and while it is great, I think these two are even better. In my opinion you have nothing to lose for $10 and everything to gain with this nice set of sharp and user friendly Thai knives

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Razor-sharp knives easy on hands
reviews.reviewText: These are wonderful knives, lightweight and easy on painful joints and stiff hands. The thin blades are razor-sharp and slice easily through vegetables such as onions, broccoli, cauliflower, potatoes, carrots, etc.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great quality, great value. Sharp, versatile and light.
reviews.reviewText: I got them for my MIL at first as a gift and she loved them, then I bought more for myself. 2 years of use so far and no complaints.
Einfache Handhabung und sehr scharf! Genau was ich gebraucht habe!

I bought this knife as one of my friends has it at her house and I used it and thought it fabulous and super sharp. So I bought it and I’m thoroughly converted, so much so that I bought other ones too!

We are very pleased with these knives! My husband loves to cook and advises they are very sharp and easy to use. It is almost unbelievable to find knives of this quality at this price. We would definitely recommend them.

Ich hatte bisher diese Art Messer aus Vietnam; allerdings aus Kohlenstoffstahl. Deshalb konnte man mit diesen Messern, obwohl höllisch scharf, keine Zwiebeln schneiden, da sie sofort anfingen zu rosten und die geschnittenen Zwiebeln dementsprechend aussahen. Nun habe ich diese Messer aus rostfreiem Stahl entdeckt und bin absolut zufrieden. Die Messer kommen mit einer guten Grundschärfe an, die für alle Arbeiten in der Küche ausreicht. Wenn man sich jedoch die Mühe macht und noch ein paar Mal über einen feinen Abziehstein geht, gibts von der Schärfe keinen Unterschied zur Rasierklinge.Ich bin absolut zufrieden; die ganzen teuren Messer in der Küche werden von mir kaum mehr benutzt.
